question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
Determine the values of \emph{t} for which the following matrix

\begin{align*}A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 2 & t+3 \\
3 & 4 & t+1 \\
2 & 2 & t+1
\end{array}\right]\end{align*} is invertible.
sols:
We know that a matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is
not 0.

\begin{align*}A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 2 & t+3 \\
3 & 4 & t+1 \\
2 & 2 & t+1
\end{array}\right]\end{align*} Then,

\begin{align*}
\det(A)&=\left| \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 2 & t+3 \\
3 & 4 & t+1 \\
2 & 2 & t+1
\end{array}\right| \\
&= 3 \cdot 4 \cdot (t+1) + 2 \cdot (t+1) \cdot 2 + (t+3) \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \\
&\qquad - (t+3) \cdot 4 \cdot 2 - (t+1) \cdot 2 \cdot 3 - (t+1) \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \\
&= 12(t+1) + 4(t+1) + 6(t+3)  \\
&\qquad - 8(t+3) - 6(t+1) - 6(t+1) \\
&= 4(t+1) - 2(t+3) \\
&= 2t-2\end{align*}

Hence the determinant of the matrix \emph{A} is zero if and only if
\emph{t} = 1. And so, the matrix is invertible for all values of
\emph{t} different than 1.
hints: What do you know about the determinant of a matrix?
